item.title: Europe Edition: Iran, Italy, Cannes: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES and LOUIS LUCERO II

item.title: Accused of Abuse, Eric Schneiderman Resigns as New York Attorney General
item.media:description: Eric T. Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, had assumed a prominent role in the #MeToo movement.
item.description: Four women who had been romantically involved with Mr. Schneiderman accused him of physically assaulting them.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM and VIVIAN WANG

item.title: Before His Fall, Eric Schneiderman Defended Women and Took On Trump
item.media:description: Attorney General Eric Schneiderman of New York in April.
item.description: Here’s a look at Mr. Schneiderman’s career, including his work on behalf of women and his rise to prominence by challenging the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: MATT STEVENS

item.title: Eric Schneiderman on Women’s Rights: In His Own Words
item.media:description: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York in February. Before abruptly resigning after being accused of abuse by four former romantic partners, he had gained renown for defending women’s rights.
item.description: Before four former romantic partners accused him of assault, forcing him to resign, the New York attorney general was outspoken in defense of women.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Unswayed by Allies, Trump Is Expected to Leave Iran Deal, Diplomats Say
item.media:description: President Trump has called the accord a “disaster” and vowed during the 2016 presidential campaign to kill it.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.description: If the European diplomats are correct, the announcement will be the most consequential national security decision of President Trump’s 15 months in office.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Opponents of Iran Deal Hired Investigators to Dig Up Dirt on Obama Aide
item.media:description: Benjamin J. Rhodes, a top national security aide to President Barack Obama, in 2016.
item.description: Evidence has surfaced that opponents of the deal engaged in a sophisticated effort to dig up dirt on Benjamin J. Rhodes and his family that continued well after the Obama administration left office.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and RONEN BERGMAN

item.title: The Met Gala Goes Catholic With Lots of Crosses and Heavenly Crowns
item.description: The annual benefit for the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum takes on a religious theme.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH and VALERIYA SAFRONOVA

item.title: E.P.A. Emails Show an Effort to Shield Pruitt From Public Scrutiny
item.media:description: Scott Pruitt, facing a photograph of Yosemite National Park, on Capitol Hill in April.
item.description: New files suggest the E.P.A. chief’s close control of his public events is driven more by a desire to avoid tough questions than by security concerns.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LIPTON and LISA FRIEDMAN

item.title: Gina Haspel Has the Experience to Run the C.I.A., and That May Be Her Biggest Problem
item.media:description: Gina Haspel, President Trump’s nominee for C.I.A. director, on Monday on Capitol Hill.
item.description: As she prepares for her confirmation hearing, President Trump’s nominee to lead the spy agency faces questions about her involvement in torture and secret prisons.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: ‘Like a Mosquito in a Nudist Colony.’ How Mick Mulvaney Found Plenty to Target at Consumer Bureau
item.media:description: Mick Mulvaney, the White House budget director and acting head of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, arriving to testify last month before the Senate Banking Committee.
item.description: Boxed out of budget negotiations, Mick Mulvaney’s second job running the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau represents a second chance for him to leave his mark.
item.dc:creator: GLENN THRUSH and ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: Trump Weighs In on West Virginia Senate Race in Sign of Republican Anxiety
item.media:description: Representative Evan Jenkins, left, and Attorney General Patrick Morrisey, right, with President Trump at a round-table discussion on tax policy in West Virginia last month.
item.description: The president tweeted that Don Blankenship’s opponents have a better chance of beating the incumbent Democratic senator, Joe Manchin.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN MARTIN

item.title: The Candidate Who’s Too Trump-Like Even for Trump
item.description: Republicans in Washington, including President Trump, are encouraging West Virginians not to vote for Don Blankenship, a popular Senate candidate with a complicated past.

item.title: Melania Trump Rolls Out ‘Be Best,’ a Children’s Agenda With a Focus on Social Media
item.media:description: Melania Trump, the first lady, launched her “Be Best” initiative on Monday in the Rose Garden.
item.description: Mrs. Trump unveiled a program on Monday that she said would tackle opioid abuse, social media pressures and mental health issues among young people.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: fact check of the day: Trump Wrongly Links Departures of Two F.B.I. Officials to Russia Investigation
item.media:description: The F.B.I. headquarters on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington.
item.description: The president suggested that investigators were “getting caught.” But the F.B.I. officials left voluntarily and were not involved with the Russia inquiry when they resigned.
item.dc:creator: LINDA QIU
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Roger Stone Says He Had Little Contact With Manafort Deputy
item.media:description: Roger Stone after answering questions from the House Intelligence Committee’s Russia inquiry in September 2017.
item.description: Mr. Stone, a veteran political operative, made the comments in an interview in response to a CNBC report that the special counsel was scrutinizing the ties between the men.
item.dc:creator: MAGGIE HABERMAN
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Him, Too
item.media:description: Eric Schneiderman, the New York attorney general, resigned after being accused of assault.
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.description: Eric Schneiderman stands accused of the very sorts of abuse he claimed to fight as state attorney general. Now it’s up to legislators to pick a true champion.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Boris Johnson: Don’t Scuttle the Iran Nuclear Deal
item.media:description: A member of the Iranian Army passes a mural honoring the 1979 revolution in Tehran last year.
item.description: The agreement to restrain Iran’s nuclear weapons program has problems. But the alternative of no deal at all is far worse.
item.dc:creator: BORIS JOHNSON

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Why Did a Creepy Israeli Intel Firm Spy on Obama Alums?
item.media:description: Colin Kahl said Trump officials were uniquely obsessed with him and Ben Rhodes.
item.description: We need a congressional investigation into the Black Cube scandal.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE GOLDBERG

item.title: What Will New York Do About Its Uber Problem?
item.description: Ride-hailing apps are convenient for city residents, but they’ve had devastating effects on the livelihood of taxi drivers and on the streets.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: The Heartbreak of Kanye West
item.media:description: Kanye West.
item.description: Laughing at Donald Glover’s sendup of Kanye hasn’t made watching him unravel any less infuriating or devastating.
item.dc:creator: DREAM HAMPTON

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Man Who Changed the World, Twice
item.media:description: Stewart Brand
item.description: A sage at the intersection of Silicon Valley and hippiedom can offer cultural guidance.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BROOKS

item.title: When 2 + 2 Might Equal 5
item.media:description: Since a 2014 European court established the “right to be forgotten,” Google has received over 2.4 million requests for deletion of information.
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The European Union’s “right to be forgotten” rule amounts to government limits on the publication of truthful speech.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD ABRAMS

item.title: Editorial Observer: Sean Hannity’s Guide to Real Estate
item.media:description: Sean Hannity, the popular Fox News host, is a property owner and landlord on a considerable scale.
item.description: As the Fox News star and hedge funders have thrived, many Americans find themselves unable to afford homes or pay the rent.
item.dc:creator: BILL SAPORITO

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Mother’s Day Trap
item.description: God help the woman who feels too acutely that motherhood defines her.
item.dc:creator: MARGARET RENKL

item.title: ‘I Did You a Great Favor When I Fired This Guy’
item.description: One year on, Donald Trump’s firing of James Comey remains his most revealing move.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Treating Workers Fairly at Rent the Runway
item.description: Companies across America have long given salaried workers one benefits package and hourly workers another. It’s time for this practice to end.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER Y. HYMAN

item.title: The Stone: ‘Transparency’ Is the Mother of Fake News
item.description: We are now dealing with the problem child of the techo-utopian worship of data.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY FISH

item.title: Trump Administration Threatens Jail and Separating Children From Parents for Those Who Illegally Cross Southwest Border
item.media:description: Border Patrol agents apprehended immigrants who illegally crossed the border from Mexico into the United States last month near McAllen, Tex. The Department of Homeland Security will refer more cases of illegal crossings for criminal prosecution.
item.description: The crackdown follows a rise in families and children who have illegally entered the United States over the last year.
item.dc:creator: MIRIAM JORDAN and RON NIXON

item.title: We Collected and Published ISIS’ Internal Documents. What Questions Do You Have?
item.media:description: Rukmini Callimachi and her team recovered more than 15,000 pages of Islamic State documents from Iraq. They became the basis for “The ISIS Files,” published in April.
item.description: Our journalists and top newsroom lawyer will answer questions about our recent investigation into internal Islamic State files taken from Iraq.
item.dc:creator: LARA TAKENAGA
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Air France Dispute Threatens to Escalate Macron’s Battle With Labor
item.media:description: Air France-KLM planes at Paris’s Charles de Gaulle Airport. A labor standoff has cost Air France an estimated 300 million euros, or $360 million, in lost revenue, and its shares plunged 13 percent on Monday.
item.media:credit: Stephane De Sakutin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A call to strike by unions representing Air France employees highlights the widening divide between workers and the French state as President Emmanuel Macron pushes business-friendly changes.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: He Paid for His Mentos. Then an Officer Pulled a Gun on Him.
item.media:description: Jose Arreola, center, had just paid for a $1.19 roll of Mentos in a Southern California gas station when an off-duty police officer, right, pulled out a gun and accused of him of stealing them.
item.description: An off-duty officer in Southern California thought Jose Arreola was stealing a $1.19 roll of mints and pulled out his handgun.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG

item.title: Seattle’s JuneBaby Named Best New Restaurant at Beard Awards
item.media:description: Edouardo Jordan, the founding chef of JuneBaby, is the first African-American to win the Beard award for Best New Restaurant.
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.description: Its chef, the first African-American to win that prize, and Gabrielle Hamilton of Prune lead a list that is long on women and minorities.
item.dc:creator: JULIA MOSKIN

item.title: The Pleasure and Pain of Being California, the World’s 5th-Largest Economy
item.media:description: A neighborhood in Oakland, Calif. As California’s economy has soared, so have the state’s housing prices.
item.description: Years of robust growth have brought California bragging rights and rising homelessness, soaring salaries and endless traffic, flooded state coffers and eye-popping house prices.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Bitcoin Sees Wall Street Warm to Trading Virtual Currency
item.media:description: Traders at the New York Stock Exchange last week. The exchange’s parent company is said to be working on an online platform to trade Bitcoin.
item.description: Following Goldman Sachs’s moves to begin trading Bitcoin, the New York Stock Exchange’s parent company is said to be in talks to open a virtual currency exchange.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: As Lava Flows in Hawaii, Agency Warns, ‘This Is Not the Time for Sightseeing’
item.media:description: Residents faced traffic jams as they tried to check on their homes in Pahoa on Sunday.
item.description: As the Kilauea volcano’s eruptions turned nearby areas into a natural disaster, with dozens of structures destroyed, residents, officials and tourists alike wrestled with its dual nature.
item.dc:creator: AMY HARMON and AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Tomahawk Chops and Indian Mascots: In Europe, Teams Don’t See a Problem
item.media:description: Buffalo Ben, the official team mascot for the Belgian soccer team K.A.A. Gent. His sidekick is a female version named Buffalo Mel.
item.description: European teams and fans, detached from the fraught history that Native American imagery carries in U.S. sports, have their own ideas about what is socially acceptable.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW KEH

item.title: On the Mattress for ‘Sleep,’ an 8-Hour Lullaby
item.media:description: Groups of people laid out on branded beds for an all-night performance of Max Richter’s “Sleep” in Manhattan.
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.description: We were there for a performance of Max Richter’s all-night lullaby, scientifically engineered for relaxation.
item.dc:creator: JOSHUA BARONE

item.title: Beethoven’s 200-Year-Old ‘Fidelio’ Enters Today’s Prisons
item.media:description: At right, Kelly Griffin as Lee and, on video, members of the Kuji Men’s Chorus at the Marion Correctional Institution in Ohio in a scene from Heartbeat Opera’s modern-dress “Fidelio.”
item.description: Heartbeat Opera is presenting a new version that updates its setting, employs a largely nonwhite cast and features Midwestern prison choirs.
item.dc:creator: RYAN EBRIGHT

item.title: Books of The Times: A Mother Keeps Wartime Secrets in Michael Ondaatje’s New Novel
item.description: In “Warlight,” a man and his eccentric friends look after two teenagers in London after the children’s parents leave home for mysterious reasons.
item.dc:creator: DWIGHT GARNER

item.title: How to Maintain Sibling Relationships
item.description: The quality of sibling relationships is one of the most important predictors of mental health in old age.
item.dc:creator: ANNA GOLDFARB

item.title: Feeling Burned Out? Here Are 3 Things That Can Help
item.description: Is your mojo a little off? Try these solutions.
item.dc:creator: TIM HERRERA

item.title: Editors’ Choice: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

item.title: Valee, Kanye West’s New Signee, Is a Rapper Who Just Might Build You a Koi Pond
item.media:description: The Chicago rapper Valee isn’t concerned with social media and extracurricular drama: “I would just rather be busy waiting on the next beat, so I can say something better than I just said.”
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: A low-key addition to Mr. West’s G.O.O.D. Music, this 29-year-old modern-day Renaissance man isn’t your average hip-hop artist.
item.dc:creator: JOE COSCARELLI

item.title: ‘Mean Girls’: What’s New in Girl World and What’s Out
item.media:description: Erika Henningsen as Cady, second from left, with the Plastics, played by Ashley Park, Taylor Louderman and Kate Rockwell. They’re shiny, fake and hard.
item.description: Some things have changed since Tina Fey wrote the beloved movie, now a Broadway musical. But on Wednesdays, the Plastics still wear pink.
item.dc:creator: CARLA CORREA

item.title: Lacrosse Casts Its Net Farther From the Coast, and Pulls In New Recruits
item.media:description: Members of the Lehman Campus boys lacrosse team huddled Friday during a P.S.A.L. game in the Bronx.
item.media:credit: Harrison Hill for The New York Times
item.description: A sport once linked to suburbs and private schools up and down the Eastern Seaboard finds converts further afield, and is looking in cities for more.
item.dc:creator: JOE DRAPE

item.title: Nonfiction: Eavesdropping on Beauvoir, Sartre and Their Circle of Friends
item.media:description: Jean-Paul Sartre (left) and Simone de Beauvoir (right) with Boris and Michelle Vian at the Cafe Procope, 1952.
item.description: “Left Bank: Art, Passion, and the Rebirth of Paris, 1940-50” is Agnès Poirier’s impressionistic history of the rebirth of postwar French culture.
item.dc:creator: LAUREN ELKIN
item.category: Left Bank: Art, Passion, and the Rebirth of Paris, 1940-50 (Book)

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: Trifonov and Andsnes: Different Generations, Same Curiosity
item.media:description: Leif Ove Andsnes, left, and Daniil Trifonov both had major presences in New York this season.
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times; Jennifer Taylor
item.description: The pianists Daniil Trifonov and Leif Ove Andsnes both assumed the best of their audiences in major New York series this season.
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY TOMMASINI

item.title: Will Tourism Ruin the Rainbow Mountain of Peru?
item.media:description: The Rainbow Mountain in southeastern Peru has become a must-see attraction. But environmentalists fear damage to the remote landscape.
item.description: The remarkable landscape, discovered only in the past five years, has become a must-see attraction. But the tourism boom may be environmentally harmful.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA and ANDREA ZARATE

item.title: Take a Number: A Census of Gorillas and Chimpanzees Finds More Than Expected
item.media:description: A gorilla mother with her twins in Dzanga-Sangha, Central African Republic, part of a project to habituate gorillas to the presence of humans. A recent study counted more than 360,000 gorillas, far greater than the lowest previous estimate, 150,000.
item.description: There are more than 360,000 gorillas and 128,000 chimpanzees in Africa, roughly twice as many as previously estimated.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Tech Tip: Overcome With Emoji
item.description: With thousands of potential pictographs to add to text messages and other communications, some people may be looking for a way to narrow down the choices.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Trilobites: This Fungus Borrowed From Ancient Bacteria to Defy Gravity
item.media:description: The fruiting bodies of Phycomyces blakesleeanus, a fungus that, like humans and plants, can detect gravity.
item.description: Scientists say a fungus developed its well-known sensing abilities following an ancient genetic transfer between its ancestor and bacteria it encountered.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN
